Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension. The vector space dimension $[L: K]:=\operatorname{dim}_{K} L$ is called the degree of $L$ over $K$. The field extension is called finite or infinite, depending on whether $[L: K]$ is finite or infinite.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.

Does the concept of a/an Degree of a Field Extension need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension explicitly mentions that the group is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension. This indicates that the concept of the degree of the extension is integral to defining the Galois group itself. The degree of the extension ($[\mathbb{F}_{q'} : \mathbb{F}_q]$) quantifies how many times larger the extended field $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$ is compared to the base field $\mathbb{F}_q$, and this number ($n$) directly determines the order of the Galois group. Therefore, without the concept of the degree of a field extension, one cannot define the order of the Galois group, which is a crucial part of its structure as described in the definition.
